word.description:
This is a [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) -- the pronunciation (ga fē in Cantonese, kā fēi in Mandarin) sounds more or less like [coffee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee).

 The first character {咖} is similarly used in the [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) for curry, 咖喱 (ga lēi).

**Ordering**

{杯} is *cup* (or mug or glass) and is the [measure word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measure_word) for water (and other drinks), and {一} is *one*, so to order a cup of coffee, ask for 一杯咖啡 (yāt būi ga fē in Cantonese, yī bēi kā fēi in Mandarin), *one cup of water*.

description: [Coffee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee) is not exactly a traditional dim sum drunk, but it's a common offering with Hong Kong breakfasts and lunches, particularly at Hong Kong-style cafes ([cha chaan teng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cha_chaan_teng)).

word.description:
The Cantonese for latte is 鮮奶咖啡, *fresh milk coffee* ({鮮} is *fresh*, {奶} is *milk*, and {咖啡} is the [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) for *coffee*.

The Mandarin word for [latte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latte) is simply the [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) {拿鐵} (the Mandarin pronunciation ná tiě sounds more or less like *latte* (the Cantonese pronunciation nàh tit no so much), or the fuller {拿鐵咖啡} (ná tiě kā fēi), *latte coffee*.
